report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Black Basta, a new ransomware gang, has swiftly risen to prominence in recent weeks after it caused massive breaches to organizations in a short span of time.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: On April 20, 2022, a user named Black Basta posted on underground forums known as XSS.IS and EXPLOIT.IN to advertise that it intends to buy and monetize corporate network access credentials for a share of the profits. The advertisement also specified that it was looking for organizations based in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand, which are all English-speaking countries. A report noted that malicious actors acquired stolen credentials from some darknet websites that peddle an enormous amount of exfiltrated data to the underground market.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: On April 26, Twitter user PCrisk tweeted about the new Black Basta ransomware that appends the extension .basta and changes the desktop wallpaper.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: This blog entry takes a closer look at the Black Basta ransomware and analyzes this newcomers familiar infection techniques.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

text: The infection routine

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Black Basta ransomware needs administrator rights to run. It otherwise displays a command prompt message as shown on Figure 1.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 1. A command prompt is displayed if Black Basta ransomware is not run with administrator rights.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: After running the ransomware as administrator, it removes shadow copies, disables Windows recovery and repair, and boots the PC in safe mode.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: C:\Windows\SysNative\vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet C:\Windows\SysNative\bcdedit.exe /deletevalue safeboot C:\Windows\SysNative\bcdedit /set safeboot networkChanges

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 2. Commands such as "C:\Windows\SysNative\bcedit /set safeboot networkChanges" are embedded in the binary and can be viewed easily.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: It also drops the following files, which will be used later when changing the desktop wallpaper and icons for encrypted files:

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: %Temp%\fkdjsadasd.ico %Temp%\dlaksjdoiwq.jpg

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Before booting the infected device into safe mode, it changes the desktop wallpaper by dropping the .jpg file into the %temp% folder and creating the following registry entry:

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Key: HKCU\Control Panel\Desktop; Value: Wallpaper; Data:%Temp%\dlaksjdoiwq.jpg;

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 3. The registry entry created after Black Basta ransomware changes the wallpaper on the infected machine

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 4. The desktop wallpaper created by the ransomware from the .jpg file dropped in the %temp% folder

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: After changing the desktop wallpaper, it then adds the following registry keys to change the icon of the encrypted files with the .basta extension:

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\.basta HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\.basta\DefaultIcon data: %TEMP%\fkdjsadasd.ico

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 5. The registry keys added by the ransomware to change the icon of the files with the .basta extension

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: The ransomware proceeds to encrypt files while the device is in safe mode, appending all encrypted files with the .basta extension. The ransom note is found in all the folders the ransomware has affected.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 6. The infected files shown with the .basta extension

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: The ransom note indicates the malicious actors onion site and a company ID. Despite running the same ransomware (SHA256 hash: 5d2204f3a20e163120f52a2e3595db19890050b2faa96c6cba6b094b0a52b0aa) on different virtual machines, the company ID the gang provides is the same across all devices.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 7. The ransom note dropped by Black Basta

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Using another binary (SHA256 hash: 7883f01096db9bcf090c2317749b6873036c27ba92451b212b8645770e1f0b8a), a different company ID is shown on the ransom note. The files are likewise appended with the .basta extension.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 8. A different company ID is given when another binary is used.

text: Analyzing the infection routine

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Black Bastas recent entry to the cybercrime world suggests that information about their operations is still limited. According to a report, the gang has neither started marketing its operations nor has it begun recruitment of affiliates in underground forums. Based on advertisements they posted before the attacks, the malicious actor likely uses stolen credentials purchased in darknet websites or underground forums to get into an organizations system.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: We probed further and found that the company ID written in the ransom note is hardcoded in the binary file.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 9. The company ID in the ransom note is hardcoded in the binary file.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

text: Black Basta attempts to delete shadow copies using vssadmin.exe and boots the device in safe mode using bcdexit.exe from different paths, specifically, %SysNative% and %System32%.

text: Extortion phase

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: For a newcomer in the field, Black Basta is quite prolific for having compromised at least a dozen organizations in just a few weeks. The groups first known attack using the Black Basta ransomware occurred in the second week of April 2022. But an earlier sample was also spotted back in February 2022 with the ransomware name no_name_software, which appends the extension encrypted to encrypted files. According to some threat researchers, it appears that Black Basta has been in development since early February 2022.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Figure 17. Ransom note used in an earlier sample

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Like other enterprise-focused ransomware operations, Black Basta employs a double extortion scheme that involves exfiltrating confidential data before encryption to threaten victims with public release of the stolen data.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: The gang carries out the extortion phase of its attacks on its Tor site, Basta News, which contains a list of all the victims who have not paid the ransom.

chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

text: Possible relation to an APT

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Security researchers exchanged speculations on Twitter that Black Basta is possibly a rebranding of the Conti ransomware operation. MalwareHunterTeam pointed out many similarities in its leak site, payment site, and negotiation style to those of Contis. Twitter user Arkbird echoed the same observation. Lawrence Abrams of BleepingComputer also mentioned that the malicious actors behind Black Basta seem like they are exerting a lot of effort to avoid any resemblance to their previous identity.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: We have also noticed some similarities between the Black Basta and Black Matter payment sites. Like Black Matter, Black Basta implements user verification on its Tor site. However, the leak site does not implement a session key.

text: Insights

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: The malicious actors could be using a unique binary for each organization that they target. This can be seen from the ransom note that they drop, which is hardcoded in the malware itself. A ransomware typically creates a unique ID for each victim despite being infected by the same executable. Their choice of target organizations also suggests this to be the case. They buy corporate network access credentials in underground markets, which could mean that they do not distribute their malware sporadically. Instead, they use a certain kind of binary or variant for a specific organization.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

text: Recommendations

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
text: Threat researchers suggest that the recent attacks by Black Basta can be seen as early manifestations of Contis rebranding efforts. True or not, organizations should keep a watchful eye against ransomware threats. An organizations thorough assessment of its security posture and its implementation of solid cybersecurity defenses give it a better fighting chance against such threats.

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine
chapter_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

report_title: Examining the Black Basta Ransomwares Infection Routine

text: A multilayered approach can help organizations guard possible entry points into their system (endpoint, email, web, and network). Security solutions can detect malicious components and suspicious behavior, which can help protect enterprises.
